Abstract: The structural biochemistry of muscle contraction is a complex process that involves the interplay of several key proteins, including actin, myosin, the ryanodine receptor, and troponin. This study employs cutting-edge cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) and cryo-electron tomography (cryo-ET) techniques to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying muscle contraction at near-atomic resolution. By focusing on the dynamic interactions between actin filaments and myosin motors, as well as the regulatory roles of troponin and the calcium-releasing ryanodine receptor, we aim to provide a comprehensive structural framework that explains how these components work together to facilitate muscle contraction. Our findings not only enhance our understanding of muscle physiology but also offer insights into the molecular basis of muscle-related diseases, paving the way for the development of targeted therapeutic strategies.
